#Summary1=(human1) On February 23, 2023, after replacing official interviews to determine refugee status in the UK with a new questionnaire for asylum seekers from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Libya, Syria and Yemen, UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faced criticism from media and refugee organizations when a leaked letter revealed complicated questions may prevent non-English speakers from completing it.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The UK is replacing asylum interviews with questionnaires for 12,000 applicants from five nations with high acceptance rates, aiming to clear a 92,000-case backlog by year's end, though the English-only requirement has sparked concerns about accessibility and fairness.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) The UK Home Office plans to replace refugee interviews with a questionnaire for 12,000 asylum seekers from five countries to streamline processes and tackle a backlog, but the move faces criticism for potential barriers to non-English speakers and concerns about increasing difficulty for valid asylum claims.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The UK Home Office has introduced questionnaires to replace face-to-face interviews for 12,000 asylum seekers from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Libya, Syria, and Yemen, aiming to clear the nation's "legacy backlog" by year-end.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) The UK Home Office is implementing a new streamlined process involving questionnaires instead of interviews for determining refugee status for approximately 12,000 applicants from specific nationalities, aiming to address the legacy backlog of asylum claims while facing criticism for potential risks to asylum seekers.
#Text=Reports : ' streamlined ' UK asylum process to replace interview with questionnaire for five nationalities
#Text=Thursday , February 23 , 2023
#Text=Braverman ( left ) and Sunak ( right ) on October 25 , 2022 .
#Text=Image : UK Government .
#Text=The Border Force vessel HMC Searcher on The Solent on February 8 , 2010 .
#Text=Image : Brian Burnell .

#Text=The United Kingdom Home Office today is to begin issuing questionnaires in place of official interviews to determine refugee status for some 12,000 asylee hopefuls from Afghanistan , Eritrea , Libya , Syria and Yemen who applied before last summer .
#Text=The forms are part of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak 's effort to clear the nation 's 92,000 asylum claim - ' legacy backlog ' by year end .

#Text=While standard security , criminal , and health checks will continue , officials will scrap the face - to - face interview step to " streamline " processing for five nationalities whose claim acceptance rate is already above 95 % .
#Text=The document , which media reports range from ten to 32 pages with 40 to 50 questions , " must be completed in English " , the government recommending " online translation tools " if needed .
#Text=It also must be returned within twenty working days .

#Text=A leaked internal letter seen by Sky News says " failure to return the questionnaire without reasonable explanation may result in an individual 's asylum claim being withdrawn in line with the published policy " , but the government will provide a reminder after the deadline and consider extensions .
#Text=Officials tell BBC News every claim will be assessed meritocratically , with the i reporting no one will be refused " based solely on the response of the questionnaire " .

#Text=A similar fast - track system backed by the British Red Cross in September 2021 for 3,000 Afghan refugees was reportedly rejected by Prime Minister Boris Johnson over fears it would amount to amnesty , which the Home Office today rejects , and strain the UK 's welfare and housing systems .

#Text=Labour 's Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said her party has supported the idea " for months " , and said it was " damning that the Home Office is n't doing this already [ ... ] including for safe countries like Albania " after the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees " recommended it two years ago . "

#Text=She continued : " Labour has a common - sense plan to fast - track cases , get return agreements in place so unsuccessful claims can be quickly and safely returned , and take much stronger action against the criminal gangs driving dangerous small boat crossings . "
#Text=Figures to be published today show a record 45,756 migrants crossing the Channel last year drove outstanding asylum claims over 150,000 , also a record .
#Text=Sunak has made tackling migration one of his main priorities , with laws banning illegal migrants from claiming asylum in the UK expected next month .

#Text=The Home Office letter reads " we may extend the use of the questionnaire as a means to gather additional information from other claimants awaiting an asylum decision in due course " , but no current plans to expand the scheme exist .
#Text=Braverman with France 's interior and overseas minister Gérald Darmanin in Paris on November 14 , 2022 .
#Text=Image : Home Office .

#Text=On Wednesday , Home Secretary Suella Braverman told GB News : " It 's clear that we have an unsustainable situation in towns and cities around our country [ ... ] because of the overwhelming numbers of people arriving here illegally and our legal duties to accommodate them " .

#Text=But media have said the questionnaires attract criticism both for making it easier for some asylum seekers to obtain the right to live and work in the UK , and for presenting a burden on those who may not speak English or have access to help or legal counsel .

#Text=The Guardian cited examples of complicated questions with over fifty words , including : " Were you subject to human trafficking ( the recruitment , transportation , transfer , harbouring or receipt of people through force , fraud or deception , with the aim of exploiting them for profit ) or modern slavery ( severe exploitation of other people for personal or commercial gain ) during your journey to or after you arrived in the UK ? "

#Text=It quoted critics like immigration barrister Colin Yeo , and Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants campaigner Caitlin Boswell , with Boswell stating : " People fleeing desperate circumstances clearly need this government to make quicker and fairer asylum decisions , but this latest move from government is clumsy , unthinking and could put people ’s safety at risk .

#Text=After the leak , CEO of the Refugee Council Enver Solomon told Sky News any process " must be well thought out " : " Moves to reduce the backlog are welcome but the answer is not yet more bureaucratic hurdles and threats of applications being withdrawn .

#Text= After living in worry and uncertainty for months and even years without hearing anything about their claims , it can not then be fair or reasonable to expect people to complete a lengthy form only in English in a matter of weeks especially for those who do n't have access to legal advice and do n't speak English . "

column1: #Text=During Prime Minister 's Questions Wednesday , Sunak defended the government 's record whilst promising a " formal update " from Braverman is forthcoming : " The Home Secretary and I are working intensely and as quickly as possible to bring forward that legislation [ ... ] in the meantime our deals with Albania and France are already yielding benefits [ ... ] we want a system whereby if someone arrives in our country illegally they will not be able to stay . "
